Authors:
Pavel Matos-Maravi, Niklas Wahlberg, André V. L. Freitas,
Phil J. DeVries, Alexandre Antonelli, Carla M. Penz
Title:
Mesoamerica is a cradle and the Brazilian Atlantic Forest is
a museum of Neotropical butterfly diversity (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae:
Brassolini)
Abstract:
Regional species diversity is ultimately explained by
species origination, extinction, and dispersal. Here we estimate
dispersal and speciation rates in Neotropical rainforest biomes to
propose an explanation for the distribution and diversity of extant
butterfly species. We focus on the tribe Brassolini to infer a
total-evidence species tree using the multispecies coalescent framework.
By applying biogeographical stochastic mapping, we infer ancestral
ranges and estimate rates of butterfly dispersal and cladogenesis at the
scale of millions of years. We suggest that speciation in Mesoamerica
and Chocó has only increased within the past 2 million years. In
contrast, speciation in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest has been constant
throughout the past 10 million years. The disparate species
diversification dynamics can be explained by the geological and
environmental history of each bioregion: the Central American Arc was
likely intermittently inundated by water for most of the Miocene (15 to
3 million years ago), thus, reduced landmass area until the
Plio-Pleistocene would have hindered species diversification; the
Atlantic Forest, on the other hand, went likely through episodes of
expansion and contraction and has probably been periodically connected
with the Amazonian forest since at least the early Miocene. Importantly,
a longer time for speciation in the Atlantic Forest than in Mesoamerica
plus Chocó is ruled out because the dispersal rates into both regions
increased simultaneously in the middle-Miocene. Altogether, we reveal a
mosaic of bioregions within the Neotropics, where species rapidly
diversify (“cradles”: e.g., Amazonia, Mesoamerica) and gradually
accumulate (“museums”: e.g., Amazonia, Atlantic Forest).
